verses.text: After these things, Joseph was told, 'Your father is sick.' So he took his two sons, Manasseh and Ephraim, with him.
verses.comment: Joseph’s action here prepares the way for a special blessing upon his sons, significant for the tribes of Israel. The naming of Manasseh and Ephraim foreshadows their later importance (see Gen. 41:51-52).

verses.text: Jacob was told, 'Your son Joseph has come to you.' So Israel gathered his strength and sat up on the bed.
verses.comment: The use of 'Israel' here highlights the spiritual role Jacob plays as patriarch. The change in his physical posture prepares for the giving of a solemn blessing.

verses.text: And Jacob said to Joseph, 'God Almighty appeared to me at Luz in the land of Canaan and blessed me,'
verses.comment: Jacob recalls the divine epiphany at Luz (Bethel), linking the transmission of the blessing directly to God’s covenant. ‘God Almighty’ (El Shaddai) emphasizes the divine authority.

verses.text: 'and He said to me, "Look, I will make you fruitful and multiply you. I will make you a congregation of nations, and I will give this land to your descendants after you for an everlasting possession."'
verses.comment: The language of fruitfulness and a ‘congregation of nations’ points to the ongoing establishment of God’s chosen people. ‘Everlasting possession’ echoes covenantal promises (see Gen. 17:8).

verses.text: 'Now your two sons, who were born to you in Egypt before I came to you, are mine; Ephraim and Manasseh shall be mine, just as Reuben and Simeon are.'
verses.comment: Jacob fully adopts Joseph’s sons as his own, granting them status equal to his firstborns. This action sets up Ephraim and Manasseh as tribal founders in Israel.

verses.text: 'But any children born to you after them shall be yours; they will be called by the names of their brothers in their inheritance.'
verses.comment: Jacob restricts the adoption to Ephraim and Manasseh only. Later sons of Joseph will receive inheritance under Ephraim and Manasseh, emphasizing the unique status of these two.

verses.text: 'As for me, when I came from Paddan, Rachel died beside me in the land of Canaan, on the way, while there was still some distance to go to Ephrath; and I buried her there on the road to Ephrath, that is, Bethlehem.'
verses.comment: Rachel’s burial near Bethlehem (Ephrath) becomes significant in messianic prophecy (see Micah 5:2; Matt. 2:6). This reference foreshadows the future importance of Bethlehem in salvation history.

verses.text: When Israel saw Joseph’s sons, he said, 'Who are these?'
verses.comment: This question echoes Jacob’s earlier interactions involving blessings, emphasizing the gravity of what is about to occur.

verses.text: Joseph replied to his father, 'They are my sons, whom God has given me here.' Israel said, 'Please bring them to me, so I may bless them.'
verses.comment: The act of blessing by patriarchal laying on of hands here is important, setting a precedent for the transmission of spiritual authority and blessing through physical action (see Num. 27:18-23).

verses.text: Now Israel’s eyes were dim because of age, so he could not see clearly. Joseph brought them near him, and he kissed them and embraced them.
verses.comment: The failing eyesight parallels Isaac’s blessing of Jacob (Gen. 27:1), reinforcing the continuity of God’s blessing through generations, even amidst human weakness.

verses.text: Israel said to Joseph, 'I never expected to see your face, and now God has even let me see your children.'
verses.comment: A recognition that God’s providence often exceeds human expectation. The theme of God’s generous grace is subtly implied.

verses.text: Then Joseph removed them from his father’s knees, and bowed down before him with his face to the ground.
verses.comment: Joseph’s posture of reverence and humility before the patriarch affirms the importance of honor and submission in the transmission of blessing and authority.

verses.text: Joseph took both of them, Ephraim in his right hand toward Israel’s left, and Manasseh in his left hand toward Israel’s right, and brought them close to him.
verses.comment: Joseph positions his sons for the expected blessing: the right hand for the firstborn. This sets up the unconventional reversal about to happen.

verses.text: But Israel stretched out his right hand and laid it on Ephraim’s head, even though he was the younger, and his left hand on Manasseh’s head. He crossed his hands, although Manasseh was the firstborn.
verses.comment: The reversal parallels God’s chosen over human expectations, as seen with Jacob over Esau (Gen. 25:23). Spiritual authority often defies worldly conventions.

verses.text: And he blessed Joseph, and said, 'The God before whom my fathers Abraham and Isaac walked—the God who has been my shepherd all my life to this day,'
verses.comment: Jacob’s reference to God as shepherd anticipates later themes of divine guidance and spiritual nourishment, prefiguring Christ as the Good Shepherd (see John 10:11).

verses.text: 'the angel who has delivered me from all harm, bless these boys. May they be called by my name and the name of my fathers Abraham and Isaac. May they increase greatly upon the earth.'
verses.comment: Jacob invokes the angel (understood as God’s messenger or even a pre-incarnate appearance, linking to high Christological interpretations—see Gen. 18:2, Judges 13:18-22). The blessing confers identity and fruitfulness, echoing covenant continuity.

verses.text: When Joseph saw that his father had laid his right hand on Ephraim’s head, it displeased him. He took hold of his father’s hand to move it from Ephraim’s head to Manasseh’s head.
verses.comment: Joseph’s reaction shows human expectations confronted by divine choice. The story reiterates God’s prerogative in choosing whom He will bless.

verses.text: Joseph said to his father, 'Not so, my father, for this one is the firstborn; put your right hand on his head.'
verses.comment: Joseph tries to correct Jacob, highlighting traditional primogeniture expectations, but the true spiritual inheritance is garnered by grace.

verses.text: But his father refused and said, 'I know, my son, I know; he too will become a people, and he too will be great. Nevertheless, his younger brother shall be greater than he, and his descendants will become a multitude of nations.'
verses.comment: The principle of the younger surpassing the firstborn is a recurring biblical theme, pointing to a spiritual versus merely legal inheritance (see Rom. 9:10-13 for typological fulfillment).

verses.text: So he blessed them that day, and said, 'By you Israel will pronounce blessings, saying, "May God make you like Ephraim and Manasseh."' Thus he put Ephraim before Manasseh.
verses.comment: The formula for blessing becomes a tradition in Israel. The spiritual prioritization echoes the idea of God’s chosen family, preserved and reiterated across generations.

verses.text: Then Israel said to Joseph, 'I am about to die, but God will be with you, and will bring you back to the land of your fathers.'
verses.comment: Jacob’s promise reflects faith in God’s enduring presence and providence, anticipating future restoration and fulfillment of God’s promises. The assured return is a sign of hope for God’s people.

verses.text: 'And I give to you one portion more than your brothers, which I took from the hand of the Amorite with my sword and my bow.'
verses.comment: This extra portion guarantees Joseph’s special inheritance. The idea of a chosen servant receiving an extra ‘portion’ connects to later biblical treatments of the inheritance of God’s people (cf. Josh. 24:32; John 17:22).
